title: What are no-load mutual funds and are they right for you?
summary: A no-load fund is a mutual fund that doesnâ€™t charge a sales fee, known as a "load" Front-end loads are usually charged when you purchase the fund, while deferred loads are deducted when you sell the fund. No-load funds are easy for you to purchase and manage, easy to do and easy to buy and manage. The downsides include tax-efficiency, low-maintenance, professional management and lack of diversification in your portfolio. The downside: You must be willing to research and manage your own investments for signs of risk.

content.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"What you should know before buying a no-load fund"),mdx("p",null,`A no-load fund is a mutual fund that doesn\u2019t charge a sales fee, known as a "load." Loads generally come in two forms: front-end loads and deferred loads.
Front-end loads are charged when you purchase the fund. They are often 5% or higher and go to the investment advisor who sells the fund to you.
Deferred loads are paid when you sell your shares in the fund. They are typically smaller\u2014typically between 1% and 5%.`),mdx("p",null,`Deferred loads are sometimes called back-end loads and are common in mutual funds offered by financial services companies.
Front-end loads are usually avoided because they reduce the return you earn on the investment. Deferred loads are sometimes accepted because they are more likely to be a smaller amount.
Front-end loads are usually charged when you buy a mutual fund, while deferred loads are deducted when you sell the fund.`),mdx("h2",null,"No-load funds in your portfolio"),mdx("p",null,"No-load funds are easy for you to purchase and manage. You don\u2019t need to spend a lot of time researching investment options or reading prospectuses. You don\u2019t need to worry about paying a sales fee or keeping track of investment performance. No-load funds are investible - you can put them in any portfolio. You can put them in tax-advantaged accounts like IRAs or 401(k)s. No-load funds are liquid - you can sell them whenever you want. No-load funds are professionally managed by a team of analysts."),mdx("h2",null,"Are no-load mutual funds right for you?"),mdx("ul",null,mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you\u2019re not interested in researching investment options: No-load funds are easy to purchase, and you don\u2019t need to research investment options."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you want a low-maintenance portfolio: No-load funds are easy to manage. You don\u2019t need to closely monitor your investment portfolio."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you like diversification: No-load funds are a good way to diversify your portfolio."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you have a 529 plan for college savings: No-load funds are a low-maintenance way to build your portfolio."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you have a 401(k) and want to choose your own investments: No-load funds can be a good option. You could choose mutual funds that are similar to the pre-selected options offered by your plan."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you want tax-efficiency: No-load funds are generally tax-efficient because they don\u2019t allow investors to sell shares often."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you want ongoing management: No-load funds are actively managed by a professional investment team.")),mdx("h2",null,"The downsides of no-load mutual funds"),mdx("ul",null,mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you want to choose your own investments: You must be willing to research and manage your own investments."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you want to manage your own risk: You must be willing to closely monitor your investments for signs of risk."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you have a defined-benefit plan: No-load funds aren\u2019t likely to be on the pre-selected list of investment options."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you have a small portfolio: No-load funds may not offer a sufficient number of investment options."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you have a large portfolio: No-load funds might not offer enough diversification."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you have a short time horizon: No-load funds might not have time to recover from a market downturn."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you want to minimize taxes: No-load funds might not be the best option because they don\u2019t allow investors to sell shares often."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you want fund liquidity: No-load funds are not guaranteed to be available when you want to sell them."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you don\u2019t want ongoing management: No-load funds are actively managed by investment teams."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you want help with financial planning: No-load funds might not offer any help with financial planning."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you want to avoid broker bias: No-load funds are bought and sold by investors, not brokers."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you want a second opinion: No-load funds are professionally managed."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you want a low cost: No-load funds are not necessarily inexpensive."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"If you want to invest in a specific company: No-load funds are not likely to invest in specific companies.")),mdx("h2",null,"Bottom line"),mdx("p",null,"No-load mutual funds are easy to purchase, are low-maintenance, and are professionally managed. However, they aren\u2019t likely to offer as much diversification as mutual funds with loads, aren\u2019t guaranteed to be available when you want to sell them, and might not be the best option if you want to minimize taxes or want ongoing management."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: The Ins and Outs of Investing in Stocks

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"Being able to invest is one of the best things about being an adult. It gives you a sense of control over your financial future and opens up a world of opportunities.But investing isn\u2019t as simple as putting some money in a stock market and hoping it goes up. There are different types of investments, strategies, risks, rewards, and management styles to consider when choosing how to invest your funds. Fortunately, you don\u2019t need to be an accountant or have a business degree to start investing and growing your money \u2014 learning about the different types of investments out there will help you make the right decision for you and your personal circumstances. This article covers everything you need to know about investing in stocks. If you need more detail or have specific questions that we haven\u2019t covered here, please visit"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"The stock market has been a great source of wealth creation for many investors. Over the past decade, the S&P 500 index alone has created more than 200% value appreciation for its long-term investors. However, investing in the stock market is not as simple as buying stocks and forgetting about them for 10 or 20 years. It requires constant monitoring, research, and analysis to identify the right opportunities and manage risk. The Great Recession of 2007-08 is a perfect example of how risky investing can be. Many people who were new to investing suffered significant losses when their investments tanked during that time. If you\u2019re thinking about investing your money in stocks, here are 10 things you need to know before doing so."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Make Your Money Work for You - Investing 101

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"People have many different reasons for saving money. Some are very frugal and use every spare penny to pay down debt, buy a home, or fund retirement plans. However, many people simply stash away their cash in a bank account hoping it will grow over time. While this is the tried-and-true method of savings, it won\u2019t help you get rich. To grow your wealth instead of simply preserving it, you need to invest your cash and work on growing that money over time. Even if you\u2019re young and have an extended road toward retirement ahead of you, there are still smart investing strategies that can help you build wealth sooner rather than later. Investing isn\u2019t complicated; even with its fancy words like \u201Casset allocation\u201D and \u201Cbeta coefficient.\u201D Here are some helpful investing tips to get started..."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: The Benefits of Investing for Retirement

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`The quality of life for most people in their golden years is directly correlated to how well they prepared for retirement. According to a recent report by the National Institute on Retirement Security, as many as one-third of Americans are at risk of being unable to maintain their current standard of living in retirement. That\u2019s because many are not putting away enough money on a regular basis.
An investment strategy that can be useful for helping you achieve your retirement goals is known as "retirement investing." This type of investing is geared toward enabling you to retire sooner with a more comfortable and secure standard of living. If you\u2019re not quite ready to retire but would like to have more financial security once you do, it\u2019s probably time to begin planning for your post-work life. A good place to start is by familiarizing yourself with the many different types of retirement investing available. Understanding these various options along with their pros and cons will help you determine which one(s) might be right for you.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Why You Should Start Investing Now

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`As a millennial, you may feel like your future is bleak because of student loan debt, limited job prospects and stagnant wages. But the reality is that your financial future can be bright if you take action now. Investing as early as possible is perhaps the most effective way to grow your wealth over time.
Investing even a small amount of money now can have a big impact on your long-term financial success. Time is your greatest ally when it comes to growing your money \u2014 the earlier you begin investing, the greater potential return you will see later in life. At Intrinzik we believe that everyone should learn about personal finance and invest responsibly for their future. With this article we want to give you some insights about why you should start investing now and what are the best ways to do it:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`There\u2019s a lot of mystery and fear around investing your hard-earned money. For many people, that means they never get started. But investing your money instead of just saving it can have a big impact on your financial future. In fact, time is the enemy of your money -- the sooner you begin investing for your future, the better off you\u2019ll be.
Working with as little as $10 per month or an initial investment of $100 per month, you can begin to invest for your future. While it\u2019s not necessarily easy to become a successful investor (it does take time and effort), there are simple things you can do to get started on the right foot with minimum risk. Below are 10 investing tips for beginners that will help set you on the right path toward achieving great returns on your savings:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Start Investing with Little Money

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:t,...e}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...e,components:t,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Unless you\u2019re a trust fund kid or a lottery winner, chances are that you don\u2019t have much cash to invest. As a recent college graduate with student loans and rent to pay, let alone the prospect of saving for retirement, you may think investing feels like an impossible task. But it doesn\u2019t have to be. You just need to know where to start.
Investing can be intimidating at first glance. Even high-net-worth individuals struggle finding trustworthy advisors who specialize in helping those with little capital get started in the market\u2014until now. The following simple strategies will help any investor begin investing with little money and see returns over time. Keep reading for more details and examples of how much you could stand to gain from investing even a small amount now and maintaining that habit for the long term.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: The Basics of Investing - What You Need to Know
Investing for Beginners - Where to Start

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"You can either love it or hate it. But investing is something that we all have to deal with at some point in our lives. If you\u2019re someone who likes math, logic, and problem-solving \u2013 and doesn\u2019t shy away from risk \u2013 then maybe investing is for you. For the rest of us, however, the idea of investing can seem a little bit scary. But don\u2019t worry; investing is much simpler than most people think, especially if you have a basic understanding of how personal finance works. Keeping a detailed record of your money isn\u2019t difficult and every person should invest their earnings for the future. Whether you have $5 or $500 to invest as a beginner, there are lots of great places to put that money so that it can grow over time. The trick is knowing which investment options are best for you and your circumstances..."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Start Investing in Mutual Funds

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Mutual funds are the best way to start investing and save for your retirement. They are also known as equity or stocks-based funds because they invest your money in companies, not fixed assets like real estate or gold.
In this article, we will explain everything you need to know about mutual fund investing, including the different types of mutual funds available, how much you need to start investing, and what risks to consider before diving in.
If you\u2019ve ever wondered how to invest in mutual funds and where to start, you\u2019re not alone. But saving for retirement can seem like a monumental task when you\u2019re just getting started.
Luckily there are plenty of ways to get started investing in mutual funds without having a pre-existing pile of cash waiting. Keep reading to discover everything you need to know about investing in mutual funds\u2014no matter where you\u2019re starting from!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
